title: Namokar Tirth Overview

location.map_hint: Main entrance visible from Mumbai-Agra National Highway NH-3

content: Namokar Tirth is a prominent Jain pilgrimage site located in the Nashik district of Maharashtra.
The site is conceptualized as a 'Jain Knowledge City' focusing on spiritual research and humanitarian service.
It was established based on the vision of Acharya Shree 108 Devnandiji Gurudev.
The Tirth serves as a research center for the vibrations and scientific effects of the Namokar Mantra.
rules: Visitors must follow Jain ethical codes of conduct.
Photography may be restricted in specific spiritual zones.

title: Founder Profile: Acharya Shree 108 Devnandiji Gurudev
content: The Tirth was conceptualized by Pragyashraman Srvodayee National Saint Saraswatacharya Shree 108 Devnandiji Gurudev.
Gurudev was born as Mulayamsing in Shahrarh, Madhya Pradesh.
He took Muni Diksha on March 31, 1982, in Hasan, Karnataka.
He has authored more than 40 books, including Vastu Chintamani and Dev Shilpa.
His vision integrates ancient ontological principles with modern social requirements.

title: Samavsharan Temple (Bolta Samavsharan)

location.map_hint: Central massive structure visible from the highway

content: The Samavsharan is a massive temple replicating the divine preaching hall of Tirthankar Chandraprabhu Bhagwan.
It is described as a 'Bolta Samavsharan' due to its use of modern technology.
The structure features animation, music, and lighting to explain Jain principles.
It is designed to hold approximately 3,000 consecrated idols by 2026.
rules: Footwear must be removed before entry.
Silence must be maintained inside the hall.
Leather items are strictly prohibited.

title: 2026 International Panchkalyanak Mahotsav
content: The International Panchkalyanak Pratishthan Mahotsav is scheduled from February 6 to 25, 2026.
The event is expected to attract 10 to 15 lakh devotees from India and abroad.
Approximately 3,000 idols will undergo Pran Pratishtha (consecration) during this 20-day festival.
The Maharashtra government has approved Rs 36.35 crore for infrastructure for this event.
rules: Registration is mandatory for pilgrims seeking overnight stay.
Strict adherence to event security protocols is required.

title: Dharamshala (Accommodation Facilities)
content: The Tirth provides modern Dharamshala facilities for pilgrims.
Attached Non A/C Rooms are available for Rs 500 (Capacity: 4 persons).
Attached A/C Rooms are available for Rs 1,000 (Capacity: 4 persons).
Attached Suite AC Rooms are available for Rs 1,500 (Capacity: 7 persons).
Suite AC rooms feature two bathrooms for visitor convenience.
rules: Check-in and check-out time is 12:00 PM.
Only Jain and vegetarian Hindu pilgrims are allowed to stay.
No refund is provided on cancellations.

title: Bhojanshala (Dining Facilities)
content: The Bhojanshala serves pure Jain vegetarian meals.
Breakfast is served from sunrise (per Panchang) to 9:30 AM for Rs 40.
Lunch is served from 12:30 PM to 2:00 PM for Rs 100.
Dinner is served from 5:00 PM until sunset (per Panchang) for Rs 100.
All dining follows strict Jain sunset rules.
rules: Consumption of food after sunset is strictly prohibited.
Root vegetables (Onion, Garlic, etc.) are not used in preparation.
Wastage of food should be avoided.

Mobile hospital units are operated to serve rural and tribal populations.
These services are part of the 'Service' (Seva) pillar of the Tirth's mission.
Temporary medical units are set up during major festivals for emergency care.

title: Mandatory Code of Conduct and Rules

location.map_hint: Signages at main gate and temple entrances

content: Leather items such as shoes, belts, and bags are strictly forbidden inside temple premises.
Modest and respectful clothing is required for all visitors.
Consumption of alcohol, tobacco, and non-vegetarian food is strictly prohibited.
Silence must be maintained in meditation and prayer areas.
Mobile phones should be switched off or put on silent mode inside temples.
rules: Strict leather prohibition.
Zero tolerance for smoking or alcohol.
Dress code: Shoulders and knees must be covered.

Mumbai International Airport is 170 to 250 km from the Tirth.

title: Aradhana Center and Massive Idols
content: The Aradhana Center is dedicated to the research and adoration of the Namokar Mahamantra.
It houses monumental stone idols of the Pancha-Parameṣṭhi.
The Arihant Parmeshti idol stands 46 feet tall.
The Siddha and Acharya Parmeshti idols are 36 feet tall.
The center facilitates research on the spiritual effects of mantra vibrations.
rules: Silence is mandatory for meditation practitioners.
No food items allowed inside the Aradhana center.

title: Prayashchit Mandir (Addiction Salvation Temple)

location.map_hint: Peaceful corner of the spiritual zone

content: The Prayashchit Mandir is also known as the Addiction Salvation and Atonement Temple.
It is designed as a 'spiritual hospital' to help visitors seek liberation from addictions.
The temple provides a space for seeking forgiveness and spiritual cleansing.
It focuses on psychological and spiritual well-being through penance and prayer.
rules: Privacy of seekers must be respected.
Consultation with resident guides is recommended.

The center promotes the dissemination of knowledge as part of the Knowledge City vision.
It houses rare and contemporary texts for scholars and pilgrims.
rules: Library silence rules apply.
